<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Julietjones121066.jpg|left|thumb|420px|Stan Drake's ''The Heart of Juliet Jones'' (December 10, 1966)]] --> {{Infobox person | name = Stan Drake | image = Standrakedesk.jpg | alt = | caption = Stan Drake inking a strip | birth_date = {{Birth date|1921|11|09}}<ref>"United States Social Security Death Index," index, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/JBTV-WM8 : accessed 23 Feb 2013), Stanley A Drake, 10 March 1997; citing U.S. Social Security Administration, Death Master File, database (Alexandria, Virginia: National Technical Information Service, ongoing).</ref> | birth_place = Brooklyn, New York, New York | death_date = {{Death date and age|1997|03|10|1921|11|09}} | occupation = Cartoonist }} '''Stanley Albert Drake''' (November 9, 1921 – March 10, 1997) was an [[United States|American]] [[cartoonist]] best known as the founding artist of the [[comic strip]] ''[[The Heart of Juliet Jones]]''.
Born in [[Brooklyn]], Drake worked in the back of a Dugan's Donut truck for a dollar-a-day salary while he was in high school. At the age of 17, he contributed art to ''Popular Detective'', ''Popular Sports'' and other pulps. Entering the comic book field as artist, letterer and writer, he became friends with cartoonist [[Bob Lubbers]], who later suggested he draw newspaper comics.<ref name=stan>[http://www.drake.org/Stan/Stan.html Stan Drake official site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050828130957/http://www.drake.org/Stan/Stan.html |date=2005-08-28 }}</ref>
He studied for two years at New York's [[Art Students League of New York|Art Students League]]. In the Pacific during [[World War II]], he did PR work for ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]''. Returning to civilian life, he went into advertising, eventually heading a studio of 12 illustrators.<ref name=stan/> Drake was a passenger during the September 1956 automobile accident that killed his fellow cartoonist [[Alex Raymond]].<ref>[http://cartoonician.com/alex-raymonds-last-ride/ "Alex Raymond’s Last Ride," ''Hogan's Alley'' #3, 1996]</ref>
==Comic strips== ''Juliet Jones'', created in 1953 by Drake and writer [[Elliot Caplin]], was a dramatic comic drawn by Drake in a [[Naturalism (arts)|naturalistic]] style. Drake, whose assistants included [[Tex Blaisdell]] and [[Frank McLaughlin (artist)|Frank McLaughlin]], stayed on the strip until 1989, when he was succeeded by [[Frank Bolle]].<ref>[https://www.lambiek.net/artists/d/drake_stan.htm Stan Drake]</ref><ref>[https://etd.ohiolink.edu/rws_etd/document/get/osu1368726512/inline ADAPTING THE GRAPHIC NOVEL FORMAT FOR UNDERGRADUATE LEVEL TEXTBOOKS] </ref><ref>[http://www.comicartfans.com/comic-artists/frank_bolle.asp Frank Bolle, Comic Artist]</ref> Comic strip artist [[Larry Lieber]] has said Drake was the biggest influence on his work.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cassell|first=Dewey|date=October 2010|title=One Day at a Time: The Amazing Spider-Man Newspaper Strips|journal=[[Back Issue!]]|issue=44| page=67|publisher=[[TwoMorrows Publishing]]}}</ref>
In 1984, Drake replaced [[Mike Gersher]] as the artist on ''[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]]'' (written by [[Dean Young (cartoonist)|Dean Young]]), and he continued drawing the strip until his death.<ref>[http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/d/drake_s.htm Stan Drake Papers], Syracuse University, Apr 20, 2009, Retrieved 9/1/2010</ref> His assistant on ''Blondie'' was [[Denis Lebrun]].
==Fine art== He was a prolific painter and created portraits of more than 40 cartoonists, work displayed at the Comic Artist's Museum in [[Sarasota, Florida]].
==Graphic novels== Drake drew comic books for [[Marvel Comics]] such as ''[[The Pitt]]''. Internationally, he is known for the artwork on the ''Kelly Green'' series of graphic novels about a young widow who fights crime in the manner of an [[action hero]]. This series was written by [[Leonard Starr]]. It was serialized in ''[[Pilote]]'' magazine in black and white before being collected in color albums by the French firm Dargaud International Publishing. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:StanDrakeArt.png|right|230px|thumb|Stan Drake's ''Kelly Green, The Blood Tapes'' (1984) with the title character right of center. The printed version has color added.]] --> An avid golfer, Drake created illustrations for ''[[Golf Digest]]'' and the book ''The Touch System for Better Golf''.
==Awards== He was recognized by the [[National Cartoonists Society]] with their Story Comic Strip Award (1969, 1970, 1972) for ''The Heart of Juliet Jones''.
